Award.AwardTitle: Albright College Environmentally-oriented Sciences (ACES) Scholarship Program: Supporting the Study of the Environment through STEM Disciplines

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The S-STEM Program at Albright College supports students to overcome challenges that typically cause undergraduates to leave the STEM fields. The S-STEM support is used to increase recruitment and retention of talented students who may otherwise not be able to afford college. Special attention is made to promote high-quality STEM education opportunities to talented, low-income and minority students. To accomplish this, early interventions for students include increased tutoring availability, cohort-focused academic activities, and optional research internship programs. Encouragement of diversity in the STEM workforce is facilitated through professional development opportunities for STEM students.

The technical features of this project centers on the appreciation of the multiple contributions STEM fields make towards the study of the environment. This S-STEM Program is capitalizing on prior progress made in environmentally-oriented science curriculum at Albright College. In this S-STEM Program, environmental science is the primary method used to increase the visibility of the STEM fields. Across campus at Albright College, students are recruited into the program from varied educational backgrounds. Students are involved with projects that benefit the campus and greater community through various class projects and learning experiences. Notable project implementation components include improved student support services that lead to student success in the classroom and their future career paths.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Several advocates for STEM education have identified persistence as a major challenge to students? progress in STEM majors. The National Science Foundation (NSF) has stated that a workforce well trained in the STEM disciplines is a significant contributor to the United States maintaining its competitiveness in the global economy. With support from the NSF Scholarships in STEM program through the Albright College Environmentally-oriented Sciences (ACES) Scholarship Program: Supporting the Study of the Environment through STEM Disciplines, we at Albright College made a positive impact on the persistence of our students as they pursued degrees in environmentally-related STEM disciplines. This program provided financial, academic, and ancillary support to a total of 39 students over five years. In addition, the four faculty involved were able to elevate the profile of the environmental sciences program and the college in an ever-increasingly competitive marketplace. Here we present a summary of these project outcomes and findings at the end of the 6-year term of the award.

The primary outcome of this work was the graduation of 10 students in environmental sciences, biology, chemistry, and biotechnology. We have 14 students currently completing their degree in environmental science, biology, mathematics, and physics. More than 70% of our initial ACES students have completed their program while only 24.5% of all Albright STEM students in the same cohorts completed a STEM degree, perhaps being attracted to more lucrative fields or less challenging curricula. Thus, with support from the NSF S-STEM program we were able to increase retention and success for qualified students of limited means by reducing the financial cost of an undergraduate STEM degree. Ancillary and anecdotal evidence suggests that the ACES program also increased retention in the non-ACES STEM students.

Supported by this award, the faculty were able to verify attrition points and devise and implement student and institutional support services that lead to student success in the classroom and their future carrier paths. Many students arrive in their first year with unrealistic visions of attending medical school, due to the social pressure and individual perception of science. While we regularly place Albright students in medical, dental, and related health-professions programs after graduation, simple statistics indicate this is not a viable career path for the much larger number of students with pre-med aspirations when they enter college. Through the ACES Program the faculty, in collaboration with our Admission Office and Career Center, were better able to direct students to majors and careers for which their talents were more suited.

This award also supported the professional development of STEM students during and following their undergraduate education. The cohort model had measurably beneficial effects, again not only on ACES Scholarship recipients but also on their peers. Information session with topics such as selecting a career, what to look for and forward to after graduation, and linking students with professional mentors allowed students to recognize earlier in their academic careers what careers were possible and how enjoyable a career in the STEM disciplines could be. Naturally proceeding from this approach was an increase in internships and networking contacts among Albright College Alumni.

A major goal of the ACES Scholarship Program was to increase awareness of the importance and career possibilities in the STEM fields and combat misconceptions and negative stereotypes of science held by students and their families. The reputation of STEM disciplines has seen a decline in both their importance and their desirability in recent decades, and most students entering college have the smallest glimpse of the vast range of careers open to them. By introducing students to professionals working in the field, ACES Scholarship recipients were able to appreciate first-hand that the work of being a STEM major was worth the outcome: a satisfying career in the STEM disciplines.

In summary, Albright College students and faculty benefitted from the ACES Scholarship Program supported by the NSF S-STEM Program. The college was able to recruit and retain talented, financially needy students; capitalize on the progress that the College has made in its environmentally-oriented science curriculum in recent years to attract students to the College and specifically into the STEM fields; and to increase the numbers of well-educated and skilled employees in the environmental sciences and related fields. Finally, while the term of this award has ended, our work is ongoing, and we are grateful to the NSF for their support of our institution, its STEM programs, and ? most importantly ? its students and graduates.
